ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: It was often a bit unclear what I was supposed to be taking from the course. More, short in-class assignments or cases, or an outline of goals for each lecture might have been useful. I did not learn much from the class and was often not challenged.

The most important feedback I have is to ensure a TA is secured at the beginning of the semester who can commit significant time to the course and hold regular office hours. This is not commenting on Shane Burgan (who did a great job) -- but rather beginning the course with no set TA was just difficult as there were no regular office hours etc.
The readings usually weren't directly tied into the lectures or assignments. It was difficult sometimes to know what I should be drawing from them, especially the denser ones.

I would have loved more out of class practical assignments. I felt the course was too slow to learn as much as we could have and I don't know if the feedback/involvement was enough to get as much out of the class as we could have. Having a very involved TA who understand the assignments and involved with the people would be really helpful.

I loved this course and Prof Spaldingthough I found myself disinclined to attend class each week. This was in part due to personal preference, but we also had a few classes cancelled or delayed, which kinda got in the way of getting into a routine. Regardless, Deb is awesome and I wish I could've recorded her lectures--- because they were so grounded in reality. Its great to have someone so intelligent-- and similar to us-- really break these complex topics down into something understandable. I feel lucky for having the opportunity to take this course.

I appreciate Deborah's approach to the subject matter. It is direct and accessible. Even so, it would have been helpful to have more support during the first weeks of class to ensure that those of us with no financial background were clear on the fundamentals. Perhaps next semester this is taught, having a committed Level 2 TA at the start of the course (and maybe a backup, just in case) would alleviate this need.
Course is highly relevant and holds great potential value; the Deborah is smart, caring and flexible with students' schedules.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: I did learn a lot from the assignments we did have.
Introduction to basic concepts of managing timber as an asset

Deb has a great sense of humor and really made an effort to answer student questions clearly and so everyone could understand. I like that she's a professional and could draw on real-life, current and applicable situations.
The assignments were awesome
Deb's lectures. She's just so real and honest with how things work in practice. That was really, really, infinitely, helpful.
Gaining financial modeling skills Learning varying methods for assessing the value of land Incorporating ecosystem services into land valuation
Professional experience and perspectives of the instructor were very valuable. Homeworks and readings were great.

Deborah is extremely knowledgable and she's also funny, which makes for good class sessions. The other best aspect of the course is the assignments, which are intended to mimic real-world situations and require students to push their limits and work outside their comfort zones to answer complicated questions with limited information.

The course was informal, and the teacher was flexible since she, herself, had a difficult schedule. The homework assignments helped me learn to use Excel and apply it to forest measurements and valuation.
Learning how to build these models where you can do a financial evaluation.
The class gives an understanding of how land appraisal works and how to manage ecosystems.
The assignments. They were highly relevant, based on real-life information, and did a fantastic job of training us in financial modelling.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Lectures were often too rushed or just not presented in a way that I took much away from them. They were not necessary to do the assignments, so it was difficult to engage with the material.

I would reiterate my input earlier regarding the need for a TA from the beginning of the course. I really enjoyed Deborah as a lecturer and valued her experience-- it would just help to have someone support the "infrastructure" of the course and speed up returning assignments as I realize she is not a full time professor.

I could have used more instruction on how to set up excel spreadsheets to do the financial projections. I wasn't always clear on what she was looking for in the assignments. Perhaps we could have done more financial examples in class. Deb was also frequently rushed during class period. The timing was a bit difficult for everyone, being late in the day and very quantitative, people were naturally tired and sick of being in lectures. I'd suggest an earlier class time next time the course is offered and make sure Deb has plenty of time to get over from work and settle in.
Involvement with TA

If there is a way to somehow have it at a more reliable/available time for Prof and the guest speakers, that'd be great. What about Saturdays? Or some other time that would be easy for everyone to reliably attend. Also, I bet there are a bunch of people that would love to TA for this class!! It would be so much fun! It'd be great to find a TA a little earlier. Perhaps advertise for it in the spring semester, such that someone is dedicated for it in the fall. It could be interesting to have an SOM student TA it as well. It seems like there could be some potential interest-- that could also be useful for the students taking the course.
Skills needed to complete assignments could have varied more. The course was largely just an assessment of cashflows, and simple NPV and IRR calculations.
Class time often did not seem all that efficient.

The beginning of the course, which focused on financial modeling basics, was clear and conveyed a lot of concrete and useable information. The latter part of the course, while more interesting, also provided fewer applicable takeaways. Perhaps in future years these sessions can be used to tie the larger, more interesting concepts back to how the financial modeling and decision-making works.

The homework assignments were very applied, while the lectures were much more theoretical. Showing us how to complete basic forms in class would help understand the sometimes very sophisticated models needed for homework assignments. This course should NOT be targeted to both SOM and FES students. Their relative abilities with financial modeling are dramatically different which places unnecessary pressure on the instructor to meet everyones needs. This is FES, and the course should get into gritty details related to the specific fields of interest with hands on modeling with the instructor(s).

We really, really need a class on how to build models like that in the course. There were a lot of people that have never done one and just supplying us with a pre-formed model we should adopt is (especially if you are not that well-versed in Excel) just not a viable option. So connecting the course material better to the assignments would be the biggest improvement I could see.
The class would benefit from a field trip. Also, a stable TA who will be the watchdog for assignments, as well as a helping hand.
Organization of the lectures - needs to be more consistent, start/end on time (esp. with guest lecturers), etc.
Broader examples using other natural resources and methods

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
We probably could use a discussion section and/or a course cap
N/A
N/A

We really, really need a class on how to build models like that in the course. There were a lot of people that have never done one and just supplying us with a pre-formed model we should adopt is (especially if you are not that well-versed in Excel) just not a viable option. So connecting the course material better to the assignments would be the biggest improvement I could see.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm an MF/MBA so this is exactly what I want to do

I've been wanting to develop finance skills and this was a great way for me to do it-- particularly given that I have a science background. I really love how this class was accessible and down to earth. Feel lucky to have taken it.

I intend to pursue and the sustainable land use specialization and will potentially apply for a joint degree with the School of Management. Basic financial modeling and excel skills and an ability to value land are essential for success in both of these pursuits.
I am very interested in conservation finance and this course was a perfect fit.

I am focusing on conservation finance, and this class fits very well into that interest. Given that interest, I imagine it might be the most relevant class taught at FES. I did not have any academic background in finance and this class was a very useful introduction.
This course helped put into perspective the relative value of forest and conservation activities. Though often frustrated with the class style, I learned a lot and am glad to haven taken it.
I forester has to be able to at least make a basic cash flow model for any harvest. I'm grateful I can do that now.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am a joint degree student and was hoping to dive deeper into ecosystem markets and valuation. We covered this a bit, and it was interesting, but I feel like it was cursory and that I could have gotten as much value from reading a couple of articles.
Introduction to financial concepts as they relate to environmental management
I hoped to learn more about conservation finance, and about ways to quantify ecosystem services.
To get better at valuation and understand how to value land
I have no experience in financial assessment or modeling and wanted to gain such skills.
Wanted more practice and more insights related to financial modeling and valuation.
I am interested in conservation finance and I thought this course would be a great intro to financial thinking, modeling, and application.
To meet a requirement.
I wanted to be able to do the finance aspects of forestry in order to be more of a holistically capable forester.
To gain basic financial modeling skills and understanding of the field

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: No, I did not walk away with much new knowledge.
I became more comfortable with financial projections and excel in general, but I'm still not comfortable with the other items I wanted to learn more about. The future was really on timber.
The assignments were amazing. However I don't know how much I got out of them because after I turned them in there was not much opportunity to dig further
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, but could have been more rigorous/demanding.
Yes. I learned a lot about Excel, environmental finance, and how financial decisions are made in the timber and ecosystem service credit markets.
Yes.
Yes.
Somewhat. It was a bit narrow in focus.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: You'll have a big advantage if you're already comfortable with financial projections and excel. The readings are kind of optional- when I did them, I got more out of the lectures and had better context for the assignments, but they aren't explicitly linked.
Take the course but find someone who knows more than you do and discuss with them
This class rocks and you'll learn so, so, much You just have to be a little patient w/ the class schedule.

Potentially consider taking either the Financial Concepts for Environmental Managers or Decision Support Tools in Forest and Ecosystem Finance courses to determine whether a full semester course in necessary to meet academic needs.
You get out of this class what you put into it.

If you are at all interested in finance, take it! This is a great intro course, you'll get to learn from an extremely knowledgable professor in the practice, and you'll get concrete Excel skills that should be applicable to future jobs.
Be prepared to learn all about Excel with very little instruction. Date someone who knows Excel.
Despite what Deborah is saying, if you are planning to take this course, learn Excel during the summer and perhaps have a look at how to make a basic cash flow model.
